Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Novel Solid-State Cerenkov Detector for Portable and Wearable Neutron Radiation Sensors
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is the potential to bring a disruptive neutron detector technology to market, filling an urgent demonstrated need for real time, portable and wearable radiation detectors. Successful commercialization of the innovative Cerenkov BoroSilicate Glass (CBSG) technology will serve a broad customer base in the nuclear detection and verification industry. Market research indicates large scale potential, in the billions of dollars. This market is currently well served with gamma ray and x-ray detection devices, but the capabilities for portable and wearable neutron detectors are not as well established. The proposed technology will close this gap and is anticipated to have a very broad impact. The Cerenkov detector technology can also be transformative in enabling new kinds of directional arrays for neutron imaging and portal detectors, helping to make the nation's borders more secure against illicit nuclear materials and providing improved tools for nuclear safeguards and verification.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project aims to commercialize an innovative neutron detector module based 100% on solid-state technology. The overall objective of the project is to build on the successful Cerenkov BoroSilicate Glass (CBSG) detector prototyping in Phase I/IB to develop a small, low cost, modular neutron detector which can be integrated with existing gamma detector technologies to 1) form a comprehensive, scalable, networked solution to the problem of Special Nuclear Material detection; 2) enable inexpensive in-house and third party integration of neutron detection technology into radioisotope identification devices and personal radiation dosimeters; and 3) allow for further testing and advanced product development relating to directional neutron detector networks, direct fast neutron detectors, and neutron spectroscopy. The research objectives include a thorough quantitative assessment of the detector front-end material response to neutron radiation and evaluation of its optoelectronic characteristics. In particular, in collaboration with a specialty glass manufacturer, the isotopic composition of glass front-end will be optimized for fast neutron detection. The anticipated result is a novel and disruptive neutron detection approach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project resulted in the development and demonstration of a small, low cost neutron detector module based on solid-state Cerenkov BoroSilicate Glass (CBSG) and silicon photomultiplier (SiPM) technology. CBSG neutron detector modules were demonstrated for networked, wide-area detection of Special Nuclear Material (SNM), integrated with gamma detection technology in a prototype handheld tri-modal (fast neutron, slow neutron, gamma) Radioisotope Identification Device (RIID), and used to develop a compact neutron spectrometer for isotopic identification of SNM.  The tri-modal RIID was independently evaluated by the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA) and Pacific Northwest National Lab, successfully completing all tests and meeting all objectives of the test campaign. New ultrafast (sub-nanosecond) optoelectronic integration, single-event detection, and fast waveform analysis techniques were developed and refined in the RIID and neutron spectrometer applications, enabling standoff detection and isotopic identification of clandestine fissile explosives with handheld devices and significantly advancing the state of the art in radiation detection. In collaboration with a specialty glass manufacturer and the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB), these techniques were also combined with new formulations of high-volume borosilicate glass and optimized for high-energy particle physics research. Modular components and subassemblies of the CBSG detector and neutron spectrometer were also opportunistically productized and demonstrated in four other applications beyond radiation detection, including on-patient Cerenkov Multispectral Imaging (CMSI) probes for cancer radiotherapy, “uSense” wireless plug-load power meters for enterprise energy management, distributed nanowire vapor sensors for detection of industrial gasses and explosives, and an atomic absorption spectrometer for advanced manufacturing applications. Each of these derivative products was either poised to generate commercial revenue or receive additional federal grant support at the conclusion of this Phase II project. These technology development efforts also enabled translational research and entrepreneurial education opportunities, internships, and a post-doctoral fellowship for three PhD candidates and five undergraduate engineering students, including participation in a regional NSF I-Corps program. Four patent applications were filed in relation to the CBSG, CMSI, and spectrometry innovations, and portions of the research were presented at annual scientific society meetings and accepted for publication in refereed journals focused on medical physics and nuclear instrumentation. Overall the project effort far exceeded the original project scope, delivering transformative technologies and broad impacts in national defense, homeland security, radiation oncology, building energy efficiency, and industrial hygiene while helping to ensure continued U.S. technology leadership in radiation detection.
